docs.lead_paragraph: In the first concentrated study of the social and psychological effects of Internet use at home, researchers at Carnegie Mellon University have found that people who spend even a few hours a week on line experience higher levels of depression and loneliness than if they used the computer network less frequently. Participants who were lonelier and more depressed, as determined by standard questionnaires at the start of the two-year study, were no more drawn to the Internet than those who were originally happier and more socially engaged. Instead, Internet use itself appeared to cause a decline in psychological well-being, the researchers said.

headline.main: Sad, Lonely World Discovered in Cyberspace

docs.abstract: Researchers at Carnegie Mellon University, in first concentrated study of social and psychological effects of Internet use at home, finds people who spend even few hours on line each week experience higher levels of depression and loneliness than if they used computer network less frequently; participants in two-year study who were lonelier and more depressed, were no more drawn to Internet than those who were originally happier and more socially engaged; result of $1.5 million project ran completely contrary to expectations of social scientists who designed it and to many of organizations that financed it (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN this dog-eat-dog real-estate market, it's no surprise that dogs are having a tough time. Plenty of buildings ban dogs outright. Others impose conditions, written or unwritten: Fido rides in the freight car, Toto gets toted through the lobby, Rover requires a big security deposit, Balto had better not bark.

headline.main: Buildings Tightening the Leash on Dogs

docs.abstract: Dog policies in rental, co-op and condominium housing are tightening with current tight market; some buildings are banning dogs outright, while others impose conditions; photos (M)
